questions.question: When you feel a wave of sadness coming, your first healthy move usually is:
choices: Push it down and pretend you’re fine
Let yourself cry or feel it fully
Immediately distract with scrolling or snacks

questions.question: You’ve had a terrible day. The thing that actually helps you feel better fastest is:
choices: Texting or calling someone who really gets you

questions.question: Journaling or writing your feelings down when you’re sad:
choices: Is one of the best tools I have

questions.question: After a breakup or loss, you usually:
choices: Lean on friends/family and let them support you
Stay busy 24/7 so you don’t feel it

questions.question: Sad music when you’re already down:
choices: Surprisingly helps you process and release
I only listen to happy stuff

questions.question: Exercise or walking outside when you feel low:
choices: Almost always lifts my mood, even a little
I force myself but hate it

questions.question: How comfortable are you telling someone “I’m really struggling right now”?
choices: Very—I reach out when I need to

questions.question: When sadness lingers longer than a few days, you:
choices: Talk to a friend, therapist, or doctor

questions.question: Self-compassion (being kind to yourself like you would a friend) when sad feels:
Looking back, the times you’ve healed best from sadness involved:
choices: Feeling it fully + connection + gentle self-care
Waiting for someone else to fix it

score.high: Sadness Whisperer → You let yourself feel without drowning. Healthy, gentle, and strong—you heal beautifully.
score.medium: Healing in Progress  You’ve got some solid tools and you’re learning more every time. Keep going—you’re on the right path.
score.low: Stuck in the Rain  Right now sadness tends to linger longer than it needs to. The good news: healthy coping is 100% learnable.
